[Satya Nadella](https://www.linkedin.com/in/satyanadella?trk=public_post_comment-text), this is the right conversation at the right moment. The best AI implementations I've seen in complex institutions don't replace the human at the center of the work, they eliminate the administrative drag that pulls that human away from it. For a clinician, that's patient time. For a faculty member, that's student time. The logic is identical.

What [Microsoft](https://www.linkedin.com/company/microsoft?trk=public_post_comment-text) is doing with Dragon Copilot is a proof point for something broader. When AI handles the documentation burden, the professional can return to the work only they can do. That's not efficiency for efficiency's sake. That's a values statement about what we believe skilled humans are actually for. The institutions that figure this out first, in healthcare, in education, in any high-touch field, won't just perform better. They'll attract better talent, because talented people want to spend their time doing meaningful work, not feeding systems.

The question worth asking isn't whether AI can save clinicians time. It's what we expect them to do with it once it does.
